Hey 👋 I’m building a website to make TAO accessible to everyone, but I need a bit more info — so I’m asking all the subnets (this isn’t spam 😅).

I already know what most subnets do, but just to make sure I’ve got everything right, could you please answer these two short questions in one simple sentence each, ideally in “baby language” (so everyone can easily understand):

1️⃣ What problem does your subnet solve (in real world)?
2️⃣ What is the goal of your subnet in the years to come?

Thanks a lot if you take the time to reply 🙏 and sorry for the interruption — I’ll reach out to you privately soon to discuss more details if you don't mind.

are you running two miners on one machine, each assigned to their own gpu?

we're going to be deploying a change tomorrow morning. i'll admit it's a bit of a shot in the dark on the tensor issue you guys with multi-gpus are experiencing. fingers crossed we can nip it in the bud with this next release.

one of the challenges we've been facing today is "how do you define fast" in training an LLM.  you'd think the answer would be obvious but it's actually really complicated. a model that quickly reaches loss of X quicker may actually be over taken by a slower model in the long run and we haven't been training any of these models for that long yet.  we need to start identifying some kpis for performance to be some better a-b testing on the various hyper parameter tuning.  we're getting there and this is influencing our roadmap.  there are ppl in our team who understand this than me. just thought it was interesting and wanted to share. the goal remains the same: training large models, decentralized, quickly.

Hi @cass | Macrocosmos  May I ask a question?
On one GPU, can I run multi miners? Ofc, GPU vram is enough
yes, I wonder the same, for example a H200 has 140G vram, running a single miner on it is wasteful
You can always run 5x instances of the same miner and see how it goes 🙂

we have not tested this.  my concern would be that it might introduce training instability that goes unnoticed.  training, as we've seen, can be quite sensitive. at the moment, we do not recommend this.

It somewhat works. But introduces other problems, having 16 or 32 miners running on one instance requires higher than usual network connection, having half of these miners doing merging is very CPU intensive etc

It is easy to really slow down the miner. Even if GPU's are idling most of the time when they do work they do it all together. You would need to make sure you do not end up with 2-4 single layer miners on GPU
https://tenor.com/view/the-final-update-update-heres-the-latest-updated-version-nailogical-gif-15335636

## Merged to Main
Hey folks, @cass | Macrocosmos has been hard at work trying to get the system to be faster and more reliable. Here are the changes, which include: 

1. Better GPU handling, and logging 
2. Increasing the cache size for miners for the system to become more efficient 
3. Preliminary support for other non-CUDA gpus (MPS and others). This is to help our local develpment, but also prepare for when we want to try and access more compute in the future 
https://github.com/macrocosm-os/iota/pull/132

embeds.title: Improving CUDA, Speeding up Prod by steffencruz · Pull Request #13...
embeds.description:
Details

Increases the miner-side cache from 2 --&gt; 8. The miner-side queue size is automatically 2x cache, so it is currently 16.
Improving GPU device assignment reducing CUDA related errors...

messages.content: hi @brian | macrocosmos , where can i set active cache size and queue size?

we added envvars in the last version to allow miners to reduce from the max value in case miners were getting CUDA errors.  with the CUDA errors mostly resolved and the impact of the input activations having a very small footprint on the CPU, we've removed these envvars so everyone will use the max cache size which has been increased in this version from 2 to 8.  queue size is fixed to 2x the cache size, i.e 16.
makes sense. so i can adjust the queue size with the max cache size
if you want less in your queue, then yes you can reduce it. But you might as well max this out
what do you think the maximum queue size would be for 48GB of vram? i'd like to max that out

the max queue size is defined in the common settings, and it cannot be made larger than what it is. "maxing it out" right now is not touching the default values. The value is read into the orchestrator (which is why it's in common as well).

In general, whatever is in the common settings shouldn't be modified, as it's read for miners, validators, and anything in the backend
we will improve the experience for miners overtime but for now, just run the base!
got it. thanks for clarifying

Also guys, we will be experimenting with integrity attestation on the miners in some runs. What this means is that we will be verifying that you run the base miner code. This is just an experiment, as cass said above training instability is our biggest concern at the moment and we want to see if this will help. Once we have tested this we might implement a more advanced version that allows changes to certain files so that you guys can still optimize
no matters if some files including common settings are allowed to be changed
anything with a envvar is allowed to change.
nice!

so far only one miner pr machine, wanted to test to see if that would work fine, i like having a default reference point.

been trying to really start mining this for over 2 weeks... i would hardly call iota stable software lol, it seems to be highly experimental and changing nearly all the time, for better or worse lol
think there has been a new version every 2 or 3 days thus far 😄

which is fine, i'm not complaining, when stuff is getting better.

the incentive balancing problem, seems a very simple one...
you take incentivizing "force one" and let it run up against demand "force two".... 

that will usually create a dynamically stabilized state, if the forces are countering each other correctly.

basically you guys want faster compute, so you should reward that.
by like measuring how many activations a miner can complete, or whatever.

ofc then if each layer is different then, maybe there needs to be more... i suppose it would be surprising, if each layer wasn't a different workload.

so maybe the layers need to be a bit more selective, or something...  but i digress... 

the point being that you want work completed and miners want to earn.
so you pay miners, based on how well they do what you want.

often you don't need all kinds of fancy, to make it dynamically adjusted.
just need good core fundamental opposing forces.

if vram demand goes up, then higher vram pays more... but again that doesn't have to be calculated in, because the system can simply look at the number of tasks completed.

atleast if they are fairly distributed, there would ofc also be big benefits to target workloads on specific hardware, which might offset a activation / task based incentive structure.

so maybe one gives points to the tasks, so not all tasks are evenly rewarded, because not all tasks will be evenly difficult to do.
still pretty sure it would or should be something like that.

initially i thought it was my setup or so...

so been trying just about everything.
Yes, miners in layer 3 beta are dying
L3 is somehow getting less activations for this new run, compared to the previous one

while not sure, if this is correct or not, but as @devyu mentioned.
there seems to be a decrease in activations, with every additional layer.
so it would be logical to assume that this in itself could be the cause.

which wouldn't exactly mean the layer is broken per say, but that its simply the last layer and thus gets the least activations.... 

maybe because the first layers don't actually manage to do all activations correctly, and thus some are dropped as it moves down the pipe.

if that is the case, then the next question is ofc how to fix or mitigate this effect on the later layers.

something like dynamic layer miner allocation, might be able to solve this.... not really understanding, how all this works...

however, if looking at it purely from and activation perspective, one would simply balance out the miners, so there is a sufficient amount to deal with the activation.
maybe favoring better performing miners in the earlier layers, and having some sort of avg miner activations, which then is the target the last layer will use to decide, how many miners is required to do the tasks.

but yeah i duno... really don't have a good idea, how this all works exactly... tho maybe, i can inspire somebody that does..
and its not that complicated to simply look at activation distribution and ways of balancing it dynamically.

so that all miners have a fair chance to stay registered.

because thats really a big issue.

If fairness is considered, mienrs could mine in all 3 layers at once, simple as that. If 1 layers is broken, it's broken for everyone, not just some. It would also solve the low VRAM consumption, since it would be x3. Current setup favors luck and hustlers, not miners.

don't think that will scale very well with larger models, and many miners wouldn't have the vram for that.
but it wouldn't be a bad quick fix, if it wasn't for the vram issue.
and triple all the other resources required to mine, ram, cpu, bandwidth.... so don't think its very realistic
H100 and up would easily manage.

Not only but it's a good estimation of work done ie was the miner active in that epoch
there would ofc be other factors such as stability, and submitting valid results and what not, which would affect the miner score.

also interesting how they are clustering, there is a distinct separation between the layers.
if we disregard the outliers.
so if i'm reading it right, it actually means layer 2 pays the best, if one gets paid lol
Is the incentive balance? Alpha got only 24 miners 😮
i'd like to run alpha 😂
201 miners on beta 🤔
All of my layer 3 miners are near 0 now, but one miner uid 138 is doing very well on layer 3. I wonder how he is doing it.

Oh wow, gaining emmision on all UID's. I see decrease on all layers, strange since I use different platforms, single/multi GPU's configs etc. All this while maintaining trust ~ 1. It seems I fell out of favor with the chaos gods. Restarting the miners in a last spurt of hope.
Btw, regarding layer naming of layers, maybe we refer to them as Bottom 0/1, Middle 1/2 and Top 2/3 - layerB, layerM and layerT. it is unlikely to be widely adopted but still some idea.
With bigger models there will be more middle layers
I guess, but for some time this should work.
There  would be less confusion if iota dashboard used the proper 0 base index on UI. I mean this is not LUA to start the arrays from 1 😄

how do you see which layer a hotkey is on?
when you can't see the local log 😄
maybe from dashboard
Dashboard > Leaderboard
`5FEmR5Rf1rX7ZivB2MaGBaYfq9xXAPSz3ttdABzizNmhWq3V` this guy is insane
running 75% of alpha 🤯

but that dashboard doesn't even relate to us, because we are on beta.

we can actually loose, they can't

because that might corrupt that data.

does seem like a lot of dots for 192, but haven't counted 😄
Switch to beta at top right
nice check that a few days ago, but i guess it finally works.

lol first i get forking timeout, for using a gif thats built into discord

and then i get another timeout 1 message later.
because i linked to @Szymon | macrocosmos miner plot of score vs backwards.

***slams head into keyboard***

so trying to decode what the pipe fan actually represents.

i guess the inactive ones are offline and those packets might be each contact to the orchestra, since i don't suppose the miner sends data between one another.
thats just for show.

its interesting how jagged, the beta performance is...

well rank's seems kinda close, incentive seems right, but locations, throughput (not sure what that means...) i guess backwards since its so low maybe

even what layers miners are on, is blatantly wrong, if you actually check it against miners
oh wait, thats where you get that offset +1 layer view from...

because the dashboard, gives them +1 higher than they are in the logs...
that should really get normalized, its confusing lol @Szymon | macrocosmos 

+1 on layers in logs or -1 on the dashboard... whatever is the most correct, i would think.

maybe its not totally wrong... but stuff like location, even on a 10 day old miner, its wrong.


so that means you run a miner on alpha, or you wouldn't know 😄 before like yesterday when the beta dashboard went live.
Ive heard rumors that new dashboard is cooking. Based on this  msg  https://discord.com/channels/799672011265015819/1162768567821930597/1417875309591527435  it should be online like right now 😄
https://tenor.com/view/let-them-cook-let-them-fight-godzilla-godzilla-2014-meme-gif-10523835079864650811

you can do gifs but i can't.... lol its a cruel world.
gimme rights, a picture is a thousand words... save yourself @brian | macrocosmos 🤣
nope a lot of miners fell in and out hence the amount of dots it just plots all hotkeys that took part in the run
That's unfortunate 🤣
makes sense.

then there is ofc another variable... that isn't stated in the plot.
miner score would have to be, the avg over the time, in which a hotkey participated in the mining.
because the number of activations would be over the full time it participated also.

so if the mining score, is taken from a single point in time, then the miners that fell out, would / could have zero score.

and a high activation miner, might actually be a bottom one, that just survived for a long time, but never actually got hit up in score.

but yeah i duno what miner score is, just pointing out why the plot might look as it does.... 
if its "ghosts" or artifacts in the data, you could spend a long time, trying to find the cause.... if its just a mirage.
SGC my man, can you finish in one sentence sometime😂
The miner score to backwards plot, might be giving a very incorrect evaluation, of miner work performed vs rewards recieved.

Yes it does, 80%.

I'm all for it ^^

messages.content: So mining at the moment would not be very profitable? When you are planning to unlock the full incentivization?
So many subnets burning these days, I thought this is for emergency like super exploits
Chill, this is work in progress, we train small models rn (with some success and great achievements). Burn will be reduced when system is ready for full throttle with big models 🚀
Do you have any advice on GPU calliber that makes sense to use to mine with here? I know the idea is that 'you can mine with your laptop', but is there any popular choice? or top secret?

my advice is to try small and go bigger if out of memory, 

you can always modify code to move tensors from cpu to gpu, but as far as i know the default miner is doing that already. Keep in mind that miner code is under heavy development so new releases can break your modifications 🙂
hey guys, happy to be supporting miners for the run here with GPUs! If anyone needs anything else on lium.io please don't hesitate to reach out to me.
